revisions.rev:
{{Infobox artist | name = Frank Shifreen | image = | caption = "Battle to the Death with Paint," Shifreen on left | image size = 200px | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1948|2|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[New London, Connecticut]]<ref name="artslant">{{cite news |url=http://www.artslant.com/global/artists/show/48018-frank-shifreen |title=Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=ArtSlant |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> | nationality = American | field = [[Painting]], [[Drawing]], [[Sculpture]] | training = [[Pratt Institute]] | movement = [[neo-expressionism]], [[social sculpture]]<ref name="artreview">{{cite news |url=http://www.artreview.com/profile/FrankShifreen |title=Frank Shifreen Profile |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=Art Review |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> | works = | patrons = | awards = }}
'''Frank Shifreen''' (born February 29, 1948) is an [[United States|American]] artist, curator, and teacher. Shifreen played a significant part in the art movement of [[New York City]] in the early 1980s, organizing [[Gowanus Memorial Artyard|massive artist-run shows]] that brought thousands of people to [[Gowanus, Brooklyn]].<ref name="frankling">{{cite news |url=http://www.franklinfurnace.org/goings_on/goings_on/03_06_12.html#shifreen |title=Frank Shifreen, FF Alumn, art against war, exhibitions and websites. |last=Spiller |first=Harley |date=June 12, 2003 |publisher=Franklin Furnace Archive, Inc. |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> Since then, he has organized socially conscious art exhibitions across the United States and abroad, including ''From the Ashes'', a massive exhibition organized in the aftermath of [[9/11]].<ref name="wswstwo">{{cite news |url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2003/jul2003/anti-j05.shtml |title=The art of making protest art |last=Hurley |first=Clare |date=July 5, 2003 |publisher=World Socialist Web Site |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref><ref name="cultureoutside">{{cite news |url=http://cultureoutside.com/exhibitions.html |title=Souped-up Pontiac |last= |first= |date= |publisher=CultureOutside |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> A [[neo-expressionism|neo-expressionist]] and [[social sculpture|social sculptor]], he is a graduate of the [[Pratt Institute]] and [[Adelphi University]], he is currently finishing a [[doctorate]] in art and art education at the [[Teachers College, Columbia University|Teachers College]] at [[Columbia University]].<ref name="rhizome">{{cite news |url=http://rhizome.org/profile.php?1057286 |title=Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Rhizome |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
==Early life== Shifreen was born in [[New London, Connecticut]] on February 29, 1948. He was raised in [[New York City]], where he graduated with a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] degree from [[Pratt Institute]] in 1976.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="google">{{cite news |url=http://www.google.com/profiles/frankshifreen |title=Frank Shifreen profile |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Frank Shifreen |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref><ref name="cultureinside">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/blog.aspx/Member/yellowcat/ViewBlog/105/ |title=Frank Shifreen currently in a show at Harvard called: Speech Actss |last=Team |first=CI. |date= |publisher=''[[Culture Inside]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
== Artistic background == [[File:TransfigurationofPontiac Shifreen 2008 8ftsq.jpg|thumb|180px|"Transfiguration of Pontiac" by Shifreen, 2008]] Shifreen is a mixed-media artist who has worked in painting, sculpture, digital photography, live performance, landscape painting, and massive installations.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="digitalmuseum">{{cite news |url=http://www.thedigitalmuseum.org/ |title=The Digital Museum |last= |first= |date= |publisher=The Digital Museum |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> His early inspiration included the work of the great [[abstract expressionists]], such as [[Clifford Still]], [[Philip Guston]], and [[Willem de Kooning]].<ref name="nyaj">{{cite news |url= |title=Review |last=Zvancevic |first=Dr. Nina |date=Winter 2001 |publisher=''New York Arts Journal'' |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref><ref name="cultureinsidenext">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/348/section.aspx/ViewProfile/105 |title=Profile of Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=[[CultureInside]] |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
Starting after he graduated in 1976, Shifreen began designing sets and props for various theater and dance companies in the United States and Europe.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="estate project">{{cite news |url=http://www.artistswithaids.org/artforms/music/catalogue/choset.html |title=The Estate Project |last= |first= |date= |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref><ref name="earts">{{cite news |url=http://www.absolutearts.com/portfolio/f/fshifreen/ |title=Frank Shifreen - Free Artist Portfolio |last=Shifreen |first=Frank |date= |publisher=absolutearts.com |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> He began advertising his own solo exhibitions in 1976 with distinctive black-and-white posters plastered throughout New York City. He later used the same tactics to advertise the larger artist-organized events he helped found.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> His work has been a staple in underground shows and galleries on the [[Lower East Side, Manhattan]] and [[Brooklyn]] since the 1970s.<ref name="nyaj"/> By Winter of 2001, he had already had more than 40 shows of his painting and sculpture in the U.S. and Europe.<ref name="artslant"/><ref name="nyaj"/> He has performed at venues such as [[Club 57]], Des Refusees, and the Boston Museum School.<ref name="earts"/> His work has appeared in the [[Brooklyn Museum]], the [[Museum of Modern Art]] (MoMA), The City Museum of San Francisco, the [[Dallas Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Vassar College]], and the Gallerie di Collosseo in [[Italy]].<ref name="earts"/><ref name="book"/>
== Teaching background == In 1993 began attending [[Adelphi University]], graduating with a masters degree in Science and Education (specifically [[special education]]) in 1996.<ref name="earts"/><ref name="linkedin">{{cite news |url=http://www.linkedin.com/pub/frank-shifreen/11/5a/14 |title=Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=LinkedIn |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> He started teaching homebound disabled students for the [[New York City Department of Education]] in September 1996.<ref name="linkedin"/><ref name="nytimes">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/20/nyregion/20ritual.html |title=Art Studios as Big as All Outdoors |last=Finn |first=Robin |date=June 17, 2010 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> He began attending [[Columbia University]] in 2001, and he is currently finishing a doctorate in Art and Art Education at [[Teachers College, Columbia University]].<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="earts"/> His specific area of study is artist organized initiatives and non-institutional art.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="cultureinside"/> His mentor is Dr. [[Graeme Sullivan]], and his focus is on "art learning" in community settings.<ref name="graemesul">{{cite book | last = Sullivan | first = Graeme | authorlink = | title = Art Practice as Research: Inquiry in Visual Arts | publisher = [[Sage Publications]] | series = | date = December 9, 2004 | doi = | isbn = 978-1412905350 }}</ref>
== The Gowanus Memorial Artyard== {{see also|Gowanus Memorial Artyard}}
===''The Monumental Show'' (1981)=== In 1979 Shifreen began to have open-studio party shows at his [[Gowanus, Brooklyn]] studio, which was a nineteenth century [[munitions]] factory at 230 3rd Street, next to the [[Gowanus Canal]].<ref name="gowanus">{{cite news |url= |title=Gowanus Guerrillas |last=Larson |first=Kay |date=June 8, 1981 |publisher=''[[New York Magazine]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> There many artists began to network. Because his building was over 9,500 square feet, Shifreen asked his landlord to periodically use the un-rented space. Next to the property, on Smith and 5th Street in a "[[Urban open space|Public Site]]", there was five acres of abandoned lot to be used as an art space.<ref name="onceupontime">{{cite news |url=http://pardonmeforasking.blogspot.com/2007/10/once-upon-time-on-shores-of-gowan-us.html |title=Once Upon a Time on the Shores of the Gowanus: Frank Shifreen and "The Monument Redefined" Show |last= |first= |date=October 16, 2007 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref>
He and artists Michael Keene and George Moore<ref name="galleryview">{{cite news |url= |title=Gallery View; Drawing A Bead On Public Monuments |last=Glueck |first=Grace |date=October 3, 1982 |publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> decided to plan an artshow with "monumental" art, which a group of artists began assembling. Six months before the show, Shifreen began putting out posters to call for entries, and with a $1500 grant from the Brooklyn Council on the Arts and help from Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation and Carroll Gardens Association,<ref name="onceupontime"/> he and the organizers selected 150 artists out of the thousand proposals they received. The artists were each given a 20 by 20 foot space to create their art, which as "monumental" consisted of paintings, sculptures, mixed media, and anything one-and-a-half times normal size.
The participants included well-established artists such as [[Carl Andre]] and [[Andy Warhol]]-sponsored [[Keith Haring]].<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book">{{cite book | last = Vitali | first = Julius | authorlink = | title = The Fine Artists Guide to Marketing and Self Promotion | publisher = [[Allworth Press]], New York | series = | year = 2003 | doi = | isbn = }}</ref> The show opened on May 16, 1981, and more than 4000 people visited just that first weekend to see the art and hear live music.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/><ref name="gowanus"/> As a result of the show, Shifreen's landlord had him arrested for allegedly stealing electricity, and the ensuing controversy increased the press the show was already receiving. On June 8, 1981, ''[[New York Magazine]]'' did an article on the show entitled "Gowanus Guerrillas", calling it "the event of the season."<ref name="frankling"/><ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="google"/><ref name="gowanus"/> On June 15, 1981, Shifreen made the cover of the ''[[New York Daily News]]''.<ref name="book"/>
===''Monument Redefined'' (1982)=== [[File:MonumentRedefined.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Poster seen around New York]] After the success of the first, Shifren began organizing a second show with artist Scott Siken.<ref name="galleryview"/> Entitled ''The Monument Redefined'', the 1982 show was held in three locations. The outdoor site covered twelve acres with artwork visible from the window of Brooklyn's [[F (New York City Subway service)|F subway]].<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="digitalmuseum"/> The space for the two indoor sites was donated by the Downtown Brooklyn Cultural Center, while sponsors included the [[New York City Department of Parks and Recreation|Department of Parks and Recreation]], the Decentralization Program of the [[New York State Council on the Arts]],<ref name="galleryview"/> The City of New York, [[Con Edison]], the [[F.W. Woolworth Company]], and the Organization of Independent Artists.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/>
The stated theme of the exhibition was not size, but social responsibility.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> Thousands of artists again submitted entrees, and the co-curators selected 400 proposals, including works by well-known artists such as [[Carl Andre]], [[Christo]], [[Vito Acconci]], [[Nancy Holt]], the controversial [[Chris Burden]], [[Dennis Oppenheim]], [[Nancy Spero]], [[Leon Golub]], and [[Boaz Vaadia]].<ref name="galleryview"/> Some of Shifreen's co-jurors were [[Marcia Tucker]], the director of the New Museum, [[Henry Geldzahler]], the New York City Cultural Commissioner, and [[Mary Boone]], the gallery owner. As before, the show was a success, with multiple art publications publishing reviews. Three panel discussions were held at [[Cooper Union]], and artists as well as art critics took part.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> On October 3, 1982, there was a review in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="galleryview"/>
Several New York artists, including Shifreen and Julius Vitali, have theorized that the [[East Village, Manhattan]] art movement in the 1980s may have resulted partly from the artist-organized and not-for-profit shows of the early 1980s, including ''The Monumental Show'' and ''Monument Redefined''. The shows made it possible for galleries and dealers to find and support emerging artists.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/> From 1985 to 1986, Shifreen had five one-person shows as a result of these events, and became a successful grant writer.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/>
==Career== ===1983-1989=== In September 1983, he co-organized and exhibited in the ''Brooklyn Terminal Show'' with AAAArt committee.<ref name="rhizome"/> Held at the [[Brooklyn Navy Yard]], over 550 artists assembled in what had previously been one of the largest buildings in the world.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/>
Shifreen co-founded the Pan Aats group with Michael Curtin in 1984. For a time he served as editor of ''PanArts Magazine'', which also served as a catalog for their ''Art and Ego'' show in 1984.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="digitalmuseum"/>
Shifreen helped organize the ''Art Against [[Apartheid]]'' exhibition in 1984, which was held at twenty six separate locations in New York. It was also coordinated by The Organization of Independent Artists, for whom Shifreen had written numerous grants.<ref name="book"/>
He has been a member of Group Scud, a New York-based portable exhibition group, who park in front of New York museums and galleries to display work.<ref name="book"/> The 22 Wooster Gallery gave him the paid position of Program Director for the ''Artists Talk on Art'' series, where he organized well-attended panels on diverse topics from 1986 to 1988.<ref name="earts"/><ref name="book"/>
From 1986 to 1989, he was involved with the international artists' organization Plexus, which created multicultural art environments. Some of these exhibitions traveled to [[Rome, Italy|Rome]] as well as other parts of Europe.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/>
===2000-2005=== ;''Crayon Show'' (2001) In early 2001 he began working with crayon, curating a traveling exhibition that winter called the ''Crayon Show''.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="nyaj"/> It displayed at the Open Space Gallery in [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]] in June 2000.<ref name="earts"/>
;''Counting Coup'' (2001) Shifreen found himself upset after the 2000 election of [[George W. Bush]] as [[American President|President of the United States]], and he put out a call to artists to hold the exhibit ''Counting Coup'' in response.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/> Shifreen found listings of artists on the internet and sent over fifty emails.<ref name="book"/> The Museum of New Art (MONA) in [[Detroit, Michigan]] had recently opened and was holding a beginning fundraiser, to which Shifreen donated some of his paintings. The director at the time, Jef Bourgeau, appreciated the donation and scheduled ''Counting Coup'' for exhibition at MONA.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/> Shifreen co-curated the show with artist Scott Pfaffman, and it opened at the Scott Phaffman Gallery in New York City on January 21, 2001, the day after Bush officially became president.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="book"/> The show, which included artists [[Leon Golub]] and [[Barbara Kruger]], traveled also to the Theater for a New City and the Center for Social Change in Northampton Massachusetts. However, the show attracted small crowds in some places, and the show ceased to travel when the events of [[9/11]] had cemented and legitimized George Bush's presidency.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="wsws">{{cite news |url=http://www.wsws.org/articles/2002/jul2002/exhi-j29.shtml |title=Ground Zero exhibition in Detroit - signs of a more critical mood among US artists |last=Walsh |first=David |date=July 29, 2002 |publisher=World Socialist Web Site (ICFI) |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
;''From the Ashes'' (2001) When 9/11 happened, Shifreen had been working on an art show called ''Witness''.<ref name="wsws"/> Shifreen, who lived less than a mile from the [[World Trade Center, New York|World Trade Center]]<ref name="zeroreview">{{cite news |url= |title=Ground Zero Review |last=Colby |first=Joy Hakanson |date= |publisher=''[[Detroit News]]'' |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> and saw the second plane go down, hurried to the site to volunteer, but was not allowed to help due to union rules about insurance.<ref name="frankling"/> Shifreen then contacted Patricia Nicholson, a local activist and dancer, about using the CUANDO building gallery in Manhattan, which had been unoccupied but had non-profit status. He changed his show ''Witness'', intended for October 1, to ''From the Ashes'', and opened in the five-story building in the middle of October. The show included over 150 visual artists, 200 performing groups, and multiple video artists and site specific installations. There were five curators involved, including [[Willoughby Sharp]].<ref name="book"/> The show received press in publications such the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', ''[[The Village Voice]]'', and ''[[The Villager]]''. As a result, $7000 were donated to the [[Fireman's Fund]] and five fire houses.<ref name="book"/><ref name="wsws"/>
;Casa del Sol (2001â2004) Shifreen served as artistic director of Casa del Sol in the South BronxÂ from 2001 to 2004.{{citation needed|date=December 2010}}
;''Ground Zero'' (2002) [[File:TheSecondPlane FrankShifreen Digitalprint 2002.jpg|thumb|200px|Shifreen's "The Second Plane," digital image, 2002]] New York City attempted to close the CUANDO building after ''From the Ashes'', though the The Museum of New Art (MONA) was contacted, and Frank Shifreen, Julius Vitali, and Daniel Scheffer opened a second show in July 2002 in the same building. ''Ground Zero'' was an exhibition of post-9/11 art featuring the work of over 50 artists.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="artscope">{{cite news |url=http://www.artscope.net/NEWS/new07302002-3.shtml |title=Arts Events |last= |first= |date=August 24, 2002 |publisher=ArtScope.net |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> After the initial premiere in Detroit at MONA,<ref name="zeroreview"/> the artist-organized show traveled around the country.<ref name="book"/> Among the artists that exhibited are Amy Shapiro,<ref name="zeroreview"/> [[Francoise Doherty]] and [[Robert Nielsen]].<ref name="artscope"/>
;''Art Against War'' (2003) [[File:ArtAgainstWar Poster.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Art Against War poster]] From June to August in 2003<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> he curated the exhibition ''Art Against War: Posters and Multimedia'', which was displayed originally on the internet<ref name="wswstwo"/> and also at nine galleries and museums in different places around the world. It collected artwork reflecting American war in Iraq.<ref name="rhizome"/><ref name="google"/> It was partly sponsored by the Drinkink Collective, a group of artists and scholars at Teachers College, and the ''New York Arts Magazine''.<ref name="frankling"/><ref name="tcedu">{{cite news |url=http://www.tc.edu/news/article.htm?id=4424 |title="Art Against War" Exhibit in Macy Gallery |last= |first= |date=June 1, 2003 |publisher=[[Teachers College, Columbia University]] |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref>
The show featured works on paper, digitally printed, painted or drawn, and had a strong multimedia component. Over 40 artists from the United States and 13 other countries displayed artwork protesting or analyzing the war in Iraq.<ref name="frankling"/> The exhibit traveled to Social Forum IV in [[Mumbai, India]].<ref name="cultureinside"/> There the Majlis Cultural Center printed over 100 posters the size of giant advertising banners, of which 12 were Shifreen's work.<ref name="wswstwo"/><ref name="digitalmuseum"/> In June 2003 it also diplayed at the Macy Gallery at the [[Columbia University Teachers College]]<ref name="tcedu"/> and the university's Lubelski Gallery.<ref name="wswstwo"/><ref name="digitalmuseum"/> He also exhibited at the E.H. Stone Gallery at [[Presbyterian College]] in [[Clinton, South Carolina]]. The show featured several of Shifreen's works, as well as work by Graeme Sullivian, Sherry Mayo, and David Garfinkel.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/>
;Artlot (2004â2005) <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Artlot in Process Shifreen Scheffer 2006.jpg|thumb|150px|Artlot collaboration between Shifreen and Danny Scheffer, 2006]] --> Along with sculptor Danny Scheffer, Shifreen spent a large amount of time between 2004 and 2005 adding sculpture to the Brooklyn Artlot in [[Boerum Hill, Brooklyn]], an outdoor space with a thin narrow fenced area easily viewed by passerby.<ref name="artlotlot">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/artists-espace/gallery.aspx/ViewGallery/128/2995/ |title=artlot second stage |last= |first= |date= |publisher=CultureInside |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref>
===2008-present=== Shifreen was a curator and artist for the exhibition ''Souped-up Pontiac'' at the Museum of New Art in [[Detroit, Michigan]] in May and June 2008.<ref name="earts"/><ref name="gilaparispic">{{cite news |url=http://artpracticeasresearch.com/?s=frank+shifreen |title=Artists: Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Graeme Sullivan |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> The show contained work from international and national artists, including a live-action "painting battle" between Shifreen and Dr. Barnaby Ruhe.<ref name="cultureoutside"/><ref name="detroitmona">{{cite news |url=http://www.detroitmona.com/souped-up_pontiac.htm |title=Souped-Up Pontiac |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Detroit MONA |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:HeadSteelCollaboration Shifreen Scheffer Harvard2008.jpg|thumb|left|150px|"Head Steel" (2008), collaboration with Danny Scheffer at [[Harvard]]]] -->Shifreen was in a show in 2008 at [[Harvard University]] called ''Speech Acts: Art Responding Language, Rhetoric and Politics''. His steel sculptures began as the collaboration with Danny Scheffer for the Brooklyn Artlot.<ref name="cultureinside"/><ref name="earts"/>
Shifreen and Gila Paris,<ref name="artistseutopia">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/e-space.aspx/Artist/EUtopia |title=at the Centre de Rencontre Abbaye de Neumunster, www.cultureinside.com has mounted an exhibition entitled "EUtopia" |last= |first= |date=July 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> organized a series of exhibitions in June 2009 along with Luxembroug group "[[cultureinside.com]]", the first one entitled ''ROOTED - the premiere''.<ref name="google"/><ref name="blurb">{{cite news |url=http://www.blurb.com/bookstore/detail/1253753?ce=blurb_ew&utm_source=widget |title=ROOTED - The Premiere, by Frank Shifreen and Gila Paris |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Blurb |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
In September and October 2009, Shifreen co-produced the ''A Bailout for the Rest of Us: Recession Art Sale'' in Manhattan with Elanit Kayne and Mia Feroleto. It featured thirty artists and thirty out-of-work professional artists. Shifreen hosted the online gallery on www.cultureinside.com.<ref name="prlog">{{cite news |url=http://www.prlog.org/10316954-bailout-for-the-rest-of-us-recession-art-sale-combines-art-and-commerce.html |title=Bailout for the Rest of Us: Recession Art Sale combines art and commerce |last= |first= |date=August 21, 2009 |publisher=PRlog |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
In December 2009, he participated in the ''Orchard Street Shul Cultural Heritage Artists Project'' at the John Slade Ely House Center for Contemporary Art<ref name="artslant"/> in [[New Haven]]. His work was an audio take on prayer chants and ritual songs in [[Jewish culture]].<ref name="nhr">{{cite news |url=http://www.nhregister.com/articles/2010/01/10/entertainment/doc4b492c2a058f0653172192.txt |title=Orchard Street Shul exhibit examines community and cultural identity |last=Birke |first=Judy |date=January 10, 2010 |publisher=''[[The New Haven Register]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
On July 28, 2010, Shifreen worked with [[Cultureinside.com]] to premiere an art exhibition entitled ''EUtopia - Artistic Visions of Europe'' at the Centre Culturel de Recontre Abbaye de Neumunster in [[Luxembourg]]. The dual theme was centered around the name and the context of "poverty and social exclusion" in Europe. CultureInside first organized the show using its base of 3100 online members. 70 pieces of diverse media, including paining, photography, sculpture, digital, video, and performance, were then chosen by a curatorial committee. The works came from 13 different countries.<ref name="culrtureinside">{{cite news |url=http://cultureinside.com/ |title=EUtopia - Artistic Visions of Europe |last= |first= |date=July 28, 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref>
Guy de Muyser, President du Conseil d'Administration du CCRN, the organization that runs the Abbaye, as well as the Culture Minister of Luxembourg [[Octavie Modert]], both spoke at the opening ceremony.
==Personal life== Shifreen continues to teach homebound disabled students for the New York City Department of Education.<ref name="linkedin"/><ref name="nytimes"/> He is a practitioner of [[shamanism]].<ref name="foundin">{{cite news |url=http://foundinbrooklyn.blogspot.com/2008/03/frank-shifreen.html |title=Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date=March 25, 2008 |publisher=Found in Brooklyn |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
